thread.title: "Selling Sunset"'s Jason Oppenheim Says His Real Estate Agents Will Waive Fees For Fire-Displaced Families
thread.title_full: "Selling Sunset"'s Jason Oppenheim Says His Real Estate Agents Will Waive Fees For Fire-Displaced Families

author: Charna Flam
title: "Selling Sunset"'s Jason Oppenheim Says His Real Estate Agents Will Waive Fees For Fire-Displaced Families
text:
â€œSelling Sunsetâ€â€™s Jason Oppenheim Says His Real Estate Agents Will Waive Fees For Fire-Displaced Families The 'Selling Sunset' star and his agents are offering their help to those impacted by the ongoing wildfires in Los Angeles Charna Flam Fri, January 10, 2025 at 1:18 AM UTC 3 min read
Michael Buckner/WWD/Getty
Brett Oppenheim and Jason Oppenheim in February 2024 Celebrity real estate agent Jason Oppenheim is offering his services to help those who have been displaced by the deadly Los Angeles wildfires .
On Thursday, Jan. 9, Oppenheim, 47, posted an Instagram video announcing that his real estate brokerage, The Oppenheim Group , will offer free assistance to Los Angeles residents whose homes were destroyed in the ongoing wildfires.
â€œI woke up this morning to a lot of friends and clients reaching out because they lost their homes the last couple of days, and they need help with places to live now; their families are displaced. As real estate agents, we obviously have an obligation to help them find a place even when it's going to be difficult, with thousands of people looking for places and not nearly as many houses available,â€ he said.
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement The Selling Sunset star continued: â€œBut the Oppenheim group is offering to represent anybody for free or we will credit you back any commission paid if youâ€™ve lost your house and youâ€™re now displaced. We will help you find a place or do our best to help you find a place to rent.â€
â€œReal estate agents need to come together and work hard for the community,â€ the TV personality noted. â€œThis is our time to be able to give back, so reach out to us.â€
Jerod Harris/Getty
Polly Brindle and Jason Oppenheim in May 2024 Several of Oppenheimâ€™s costars and brokers commented on his video, also extending their support.
Los Angeles agents Davina Potratz and Mary Bonnet commented, â€œYes, ready to serve ðŸ™ðŸ’¯â¤ï¸,â€ and â€œâ¤ï¸â¤ï¸â¤ï¸â¤ï¸,â€ respectively.
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Orange County agents also offered their help. â€œWe are ready to help down in OC! â¤ï¸,â€ wrote Polly Brindle . â€œlove this ðŸ‘â¤ï¸,â€ added Alexandra Jarvis .
Related: Celebrity Hairstylist Jen Atkin Shares Loss of L.A. Home from Wildfires in Emotional Posts: 'Too Much to Comprehend'
Along with the Oppenheim Group assisting those displaced, Mauricio Umanskyâ€™s real estate company, The Agency, is working to find solutions for those in need, per Housing Wire .
In an Instagram Story on Thursday, Jan. 9, Umansky said his office is having an emergency meeting to learn how to advise and communicate with clients and agents and "try to find housing." He noted heâ€™s speaking with developers and lenders to â€œfigure outâ€ whether their properties will be available for short-term lease agreements for in-need clients.
JC Olivera/WireImage
Mauricio Umansky in March 2023 Related: L.A. Fires Live: Death Toll Unknown, Officials Now Say, as Blazes Continue to Burn Through the Region

USA TODAY Screaming flyer causes hour-long flight delay after refusing to wear seatbelt NY Post UnitedHealthcare Calls Doctor Mid Surgery To Ask If Her Patientâ€™s Overnight Stay Is Necessary Futurism The two real estate companies are offering their help after thousands of structures have been affected in what has already been the most destructive firestorm in the cityâ€™s history.
Multiple wildfires have been raging across Los Angeles County, including the Palisades Fire in the Pacific Palisades and Malibu areas and the Eaton Fire in Pasadena and Altadena. At the time of publication, both the Palisades Fire and the Eaton Fire are 0% contained.
Los Angeles County Sheriff Robert Luna says the death toll from the L.A. fires is currently unknown, despite previous reports. At a press briefing on Thursday, Jan. 9, Luna said he was â€œnot satisfiedâ€ with the preliminary information he received but noted that people â€œare doing their bestâ€ amid the difficult conditions.
